Award.AwardTitle: Analytic Methods for the Random Matrix Universality Class
Award.AbstractNarration:
The investigator will study random matrices, a field originating with Eugene Wigner's idea that random matrices model spectral behavior of physical systems. Over the years random matrices have found applications beyond pure mathematics, and are being used in statistics, computer science, telecommunications, and more generally information networks. This research project's focus is universality -- the phenomenon that the limiting spectral statistics depend only on the symmetry type and not on other details of the underlying system. Random matrix statistics now find use in many aspects of integrable systems, growth models, and number theory. Deep progress has been achieved in the past years, and universality has been established for a growing class of random matrices. This project will advance understanding in this fundamental area.

This project explores the following research topics:
(1) Universality and quantum unique ergodicity for random band matrices. The motivation is to try to approach the Anderson transition via these toy models for random Schrodinger operators on a lattice.
(2) Perturbative analysis of eigenvectors in a non-perturbative regime, via the eigenvector moment flow, a new random walk introduced recently.
(3) Log-correlated fields and random spectra. This includes individual fluctuations of eigenvalues of Wigner matrices and beta ensembles.
(4) Extremal statistics of random matrices, through the largest and smallest gaps, and extremes of characteristic polynomials.
(5) A study of non-Hermitian random matrix theory, with connections between 2D Coulomb gases and the Gaussian free field.
In order to understand Wigner's vision, in their recent proofs of fixed energy universality and eigenvector universality the investigator and collaborators developed new tools of interest for the above projects. These include random walks in dynamic random environments, coupling methods, and homogenization theory for partial differential equations with time-dependent random coefficients.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI's research lies in probability theory, through the study of correlated systems which arise in physics, chemistry, computer science, biology, pure and applied mathematics. For such complex systems, the PI is interested in both typical and extremal statistics.

Since its discovery more than two hundred years ago the Gaussian distribution has proved to be an incredibly versatile and robust tool explaining randomness in the physical world, under the assumption of some underlying independence. Systems accurately described in terms of this distribution are said to be in the Gaussian universality class. For many correlated systems, another class emerged in the past fifty years, initially from calculations on random linear operators. This random matrix universality} was proposed by the physicist Wigner, first as a model for stable energy levels of typical heavy nuclei.

The models he introduced have since been understood to connect to many areas of science, including integrable systems, growth models, analytic number theory and multivariate statistics.

Ongoing efforts to understand this universality class are essentially of two types. First,  integrability consists in finding possibly new statistics for a few, rigid models, with methods including combinatorics andrepresentation theory. Second, universality means enlarging the range of models with random matrix statistics, through probabilistic methods. The PI's focus is mainly in the second area, i.e. developing new analytic tools to advance our understanding of universality. More precisely, the PI's 's contribution have been in the following aspects of universality.

The Wigner-Dyson-Mehta conjecture. As a first test for his paradigm, Wigner conjectured -- together with Dyson and Mehta -- that the microscopic eigenvalue statistics of large symmetric matrices with independent coordinates -- so-called Wigner matrices -- do not depend on the distribution of the matrix elements. This is an analogue of the central limit theorem, but for eigenvalue statistics at the microscopic scale. After important breakthroughs in the past ten years, the Wigner-Dyson-Mehta conjecture was recently proved, in terms of convergence of correlation function for any fixed energy level, in the PI's work with Erdos, Yau and Yin. 

Delocalization and universality beyond mean field. In Wigner's original theory, the eigenvectors play no role. However, their statistics are essential in view of a famous dichotomy of spectral behaviours, widely studied since Anderson's tight binding model for conductor-insulator transition: random matrix eigenvalue distributions should coincide with delocalization of eigenstates, while Poisson and Gaussian universality classes for the spectrum occur together with localization.

The localized phase is well understood since the early work of Frohlich and Spencer, but delocalization and random matrix universality have still not been proved for any operator relevant in physics. Indeed Wigner matrices are mean field models -- all matrix entries are random -- which strongly limits their physical relevance. An outstanding problem consists in proving the Anderson transition phenomenon for at least one model.

One well-known such model is given by band matrices: each point in space randomly interacts only with a finite-range of neighbours. These matrices are believed to exhibit the insulator-conducting transition, as famously conjectured twenty five years ago by Fyodorov and Mirlin: for example, in dimension 1, if the random band has width greater than $N^{1/2}$, with $N$ the matrix dimension, the system is supposedly delocalized, otherwise it is localized. Very little is known about the delocalized phase. Erdos, Yau, Yin, and the PI introduced a mean field reduction technique to identify the eigenvalue statistics for slightly non mean field band matrices. Using a new combinatorial identity, Yau, Yin and the PI proved the delocalized phase persists up to a band width $N^{3/4}$ in dimension 1. 

Universality of extremal statistics. The above paragraphs describe the PI's work on typical random matrix statistics. He is also interested in extending Wigner's prediction to extremal events. For example, increasing evidence suggests that the extremal statistics of so-called log-correlated systems are universal. Random matrices are such a log-correlated system, and so are the high values of the Riemann zeta function along the critical axis.

Based on this analogy, Fyodorov and Keating recently conjectured that typical local extrema of the Riemann zeta function along the critical line have the same fluctuations as the maximum of the characteristic polynomial of random matrices. Their heuristics relied on the replica trick of the partition function, a method notoriously hard to be made rigorous.

 Together with Arguin and Belius, the PI recently obtained the first order of their conjecture for integrable random matrices. For the proof, they avoid the replica trick, identifying instead a tree structure behind the characteristic polynomial of random unitary matrices. Our work connects random matrices and branching processes.

With Radziwill and Soundararajan, they also applied this branching idea to the maximum of the Riemann zeta function on random intervals along the critical line, proving unconditionally this part of the Fyodorov Keating conjecture.
